title: Mother's horror after finding a needle inside a GRAPE she bought from Aldi
text:
A mother has been left horror-stricken after she found a needle inside a grape she purchased from Aldi.

Chloe Shaw, from Melbourne, posted a photo to Facebook on Sunday of the tampered berries she bought from the store in Caroline Springs.

In the post, which has since gone viral, the mother-of-two urged others to check their food before consumption.

Chloe Shaw, from Melbourne, posted a photo (pictured) to Facebook on Sunday of the tampered berries she bought from Aldi in Caroline Springs

In the post (pictured), which has since gone viral, the mother-of-two urged others to check their food before consumption

'Please check all your grapes before eating especially if your giving them to your kids!,' she wrote.

She said both the police and the store had been notified and encouraged readers to 'spread the word'.

Victoria Police have confirmed they are investigating the complaint.

Some commenters quickly related the incident to the 2018 strawberry industry crisis that swept across the nation when several suppliers' goods were contaminated by needles and produce was pulled from shelves.

'Here we go again,' one comment read.

Another wrote: 'Oh my this is getting ridiculous'

Some commenters quickly related the incident (pictured) to the 2018 strawberry industry crisis that swept across the nation when several suppliers' goods were contaminated by needles and produce was pulled from shelves.

Others felt angry and condemned those who purposely spike fruit.

'The people doing this are seriously sick in the head!' one person declared.

Another woman added: 'It's bad enough our farmers are struggling to even keep crops alive in the drought.. those that do have theirs jeopardised by idiots'

'Wtf is wrong with people.. I say when these people are caught we should make them eat the fruit. Wonder if they would do it again,' one man suggested.

Others felt angry and condemned those who purposely spike fruit (comment pictured)

In September 2018, 68 strawberry brands were affected nationwide after 230 incidents of needle contamination were reported.

The scare ushered in new legislation for heavier penalties, and disgruntled former strawberry farm employee, My Ut Trinh, 50, was charged with seven counts of contamination.

The scandal, which was also attributed to the work of copycats, cost the industry severe financial damages through destruction of crops and sale losses.

Ms Shaw's find comes after police confirmed they were investigating needles being found in strawberries at a Fairfield store in August and another strawberry bought at Eltham in September.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted Aldi for comment.
